title: Protocol for the generation of HIV-1 genomic RNA with altered levels of N6-methyladenosine
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Generation of FTO or ALKBH5 KO HEK293T cells
Timing: 5 weeks
The purpose of this step is to generate HIV-1 producer cells that do not express one of the m6A erasers, allowing for the production of HIV-1 containing elevated levels of m6A.
Produce LentiCRISPR v2 lentiviral particles.
Prepare plasmids using a commercially available kit such as Nucleobond Xtra Midi Kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol which can be found here: NuceloBond Xtra[href=https://www.mn-net.com/media/pdf/ed/82/0f/Instruction-NucleoBond-Xtra.pdf] Midi. Dissolve DNA pellet in 10 mM Tris, 1 mM EDTA pH 8.0.
Seed 5 × 106 HEK293T cells per 10-cm diameter culture dish in 10 mL of complete medium. Seed one dish per lentiviral vector. Cells should be ∼70% confluent at the time of transfection (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 16 h.
Transfect cells.
Dilute DNA by adding three plasmids (maximum 15 μL) to 1.5 mL OPTI-MEM:

Dilute 1 mg/mL PEI solution by adding 70 μL PEI to 1.5 mL OPTI-MEM.
Add diluted DNA to diluted PEI, mix and incubate for 15 min at 22°C.
Transfer cells from incubator to biosafety cabinet.
Gently add DNA:PEI mix dropwise to cells. Swirl gently to disperse the mixture evenly without disturbing the cell monolayer.
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 6 h.
Remove the cell culture medium containing the transfection mixture and carefully replace with fresh complete medium.
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 48 h.
Collect culture medium and transfer to a 15 mL conical tube.
Centrifuge at 1,000 × g for 10 min at 22°C.
Pass supernatant through 0.45 μm syringe filter to remove remaining cellular debris.

Use medium containing lentiviral particles immediately for transduction or aliquot 1 mL medium containing lentiviral particles per screw cap cryotube to freeze on dry ice for storage at −80°C.
Alternatives: There may be batch-to-batch variability of transfection efficiency for different preparations of PEI. Therefore, the appropriate PEI:DNA (μg:μg) ratio should be determined empirically. Alternatively, any transfection reagent may be used. If desired, culture supernatants containing lentivirus may be collected at 48 and 72 h post-transfection and stored either separately or combined. If combining, supernatant collected at 48 h can be stored at 4°C and combined with culture supernatant collected at 72 h post-transfection.
Pause point: Lentivirus can be stored at −80°C until proceeding to the next step.
Transduce HEK293T cells with LentiCRISPR v2 lentiviral particles and select transduced cells.

Figure 1. Optimal cell confluency at the time of transfection
(A) HEK293T cells were plated at a density of 5 × 106 cells per 10-cm diameter culture dish, resulting in ∼70% confluency 16 h after plating.
(B) HEK293T cells were plated at a density of 3 × 106 cells per 10-cm diameter culture dish, resulting in ∼40% confluency 16 h after plating. Scale bars represent 100 μm.
Seed 2 × 106 HEK293T cells per 6-cm diameter culture dish in 5 mL of complete medium. Cells should be ∼50% confluent at the time of transduction. Include a dish for mock transduction to be used as a selection control.
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 16 h.
Remove culture medium.
Add 1 mL medium with lentiviral particles containing 8 μg/mL polybrene (or complete medium for mock).
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 2 h with occasional rocking back and forth.
Add 4 mL complete medium.
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Carefully replace culture medium.

Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Replace culture medium with complete medium containing the appropriate concentration of puromycin. In our hands, 1 μg/mL puromycin kills all untransduced cells within 5 days. We recommend performing a kill curve using your HEK293T cells prior to selecting transduced cells to determine the optimal concentration for selection (0.5, 0.8, 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0 μg/mL puromycin). If cells are confluent, split the cells so that they are ∼80% confluent the next day and then add selective medium.
Continue selection, replacing medium every other day with fresh puromycin until all cells in the mock transduced control dish are dead. Ideally selection will take 3–5 days.
Once selection is complete, freeze a batch of the polyclonal cell population prior to clonal selection.
Select clonal populations of KO cells.
Dilute cells to 5 cells/mL in complete growth medium containing puromycin.
Seed each well of four 96-well dishes with 100 μL of the cell suspension.
As a positive control, seed one well with 1 × 104 cells. This will aid in focusing the microscope for quick scanning of wells that contain clones.
Allow clones derived from single cells to grow out for ∼2 weeks; change the medium every 3–5 days if medium becomes yellow.
Critical: Single clones should be monitored routinely and transferred to a larger well once confluence is reached. In addition to microscopic examination of cells, changes in the color of the culture medium can indicate clones that are ready to be transferred.
Once cells are confluent, expand each clone to one well of a 12-well dish.
When 12-well is confluent, use half of the cells for Western blot analysis of m6A eraser expression. Keep the other half in culture and continue to amplify.

Aim to screen ≥20 individual clones for KO of FTO or ALKBH5.
Screen clonal populations of KO cells. (See step 8 for more details).
Perform Western blot using cell lysate from each clone. Run control lysates from parental HEK293T cells on each gel to determine expression levels of erasers in unedited cells.
Discard clones that retain eraser expression.
Prepare several vials of low passage frozen stocks of confirmed KO clones.
Generation of FTO or ALKBH5 OE HEK293T cells
Timing: 3 days
The purpose of this step is to generate HIV-1 producer cells that overexpress one of the m6A erasers, allowing for the production of HIV-1 containing reduced levels of m6A.
Transfect cells with FTO or ALKBH5 expression plasmids or vector control.
Seed twenty 10-cm diameter cell culture dishes with 3 × 106 HEK293T cells in 10 mL of complete medium. Half of the cells will be transfected with vector control plasmid and half with eraser overexpression plasmid. Cells should be ∼40% confluent at the time of transfection (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 16 h.
Transfect cells. Refer to above section 1c for details. The numbers below are per 10-cm diameter dish. Make a master mix for multiple dishes. The number of dishes can be scaled up or down as necessary.
Dilute each plasmid DNA by adding 12 μg plasmid to 1.5 mL OPTI-MEM.
Dilute PEI by adding 60 μL PEI to 1.5 mL OPTI-MEM.
Add diluted DNA to diluted PEI and incubate for 15 min at 22°C.
Proceed immediately to step 6.
HIV-1 production using FTO/ALKBH5 KO or FTO/ALKBH5 OE HEK293T cells
Timing: 2–3 days
The purpose of this step is to produce HIV-1 containing altered levels of m6A.
Use the Biosafety Precautions after transfection of cells with HIV-1 proviral DNA plasmid (pNL4-3).

Transfect cells (5 × 106 per 10-cm diameter dish) with pNL4-3 proviral plasmid.
Repeat steps 5c–5g with 12 μg pNL4-3 per dish. Cells should be ∼70% confluent at the time of pNL4-3 transfection.
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 48 h.
Collect and clarify the virus-containing supernatant.
Collect the media from cells and transfer to a 50 mL conical tube. Combine up to 40 mL supernatant (from four 10-cm diameter dishes) in a single tube.
Centrifuge at 1,500 × g for 5 min at 22°C.
Pass supernatant through a 0.45 μm syringe filter into a fresh 50 mL conical tube.
Remove 5 mL supernatant and save for p24 measurement and HIV-1 titer determination. For detailed protocols, please refer to (Janas and Wu, 2009[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).
Collect protein from one dish of cells per condition for Western blot analysis.
Wash cells once gently with 10 mL cold PBS.
Completely remove PBS wash.
Add 1 mL radioimmunoprecipitation assay (RIPA) buffer with protease inhibitor cocktail directly to dish.
Alternatives: Commercially available or other detergent-based cell lysis buffers compatible with Western blot may be used as an alternative to RIPA buffer.
Use cell lifter to scrape cells to one side of dish.
Transfer cell lysate to a 1.5 mL tube on ice.
Rotate lysate at 10 rpm for 20 min at 4°C.
Centrifuge at top speed (at least 13,200 × g) for 30 min at 4°C.
Transfer supernatant to fresh 1.5 mL tube.
Pause point: Cell lysate can be stored at −80°C until performing bicinchoninic acid (BCA) protein assay and Western blot analysis.
Perform BCA Protein Assay according to manufacturer’s protocol which can be found here: Pierce BCA Protein Assay[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2FMAN0011430_Pierce_BCA_Protein_Asy_UG.pdf].
Use 20 μg total protein per lane for Western blot analysis using standard protocol.

Pellet the virus through a sucrose cushion to purify and concentrate.
Transfer 3 mL of 25% Sucrose in TNE buffer to the bottom of a 38.5 mL thinwall ultracentrifuge tube.
Very carefully add up to 35 mL of supernatant containing HIVNL4-3 (from step 7c) slowly down the side of the tube to the top of the sucrose cushion using a pipet aid. There should be a sharp demarcation between the layers of sucrose and supernatant. Handle tubes carefully to avoid mixing of the layers.
Place the ultracentrifuge tubes carefully in SW32Ti rotor buckets and affix lids. Weigh each bucket and record the weight to the 1/100th gram.
Balance the weight of each tube using DMEM (without additives).
Place the tubes in sealed bucket and hang in pre-chilled SW32Ti rotor.
Centrifuge at 28,000 rpm for 1.5 h at 4°C using slow acceleration and deceleration setting of the centrifuge to avoid disturbing the layers/pellet.
Critical: Carefully read the manual for the ultracentrifuge and rotor prior to use. Ultracentrifuge tubes need to contain enough liquid volume to avoid collapsing during ultracentrifugation. Tubes containing less than 35 mL of virus-containing supernatant should be brought to 35 mL with DMEM without additives so that the total volume of sucrose and supernatant is 38 mL. If using a different ultracentrifuge rotor, compatible thinwall tubes must be used with the appropriate fill volume, adjusting the volume of sucrose cushion accordingly. Tubes contain infectious virus and should never be open outside of an appropriate biosafety cabinet. Tubes should be weighed on a balance while inside the swinging bucket with the lid on. Weight of opposing buckets should be exactly the same to avoid damage to the ultracentrifuge.
Carefully remove the buckets from the rotor and transfer them to the biosafety cabinet.
Discard the supernatant by vacuum or decanting.

Critical: Supernatant should be decontaminated in a final concentration of 10% bleach for 30 min (or according to institutional regulations) prior to disposal.
Invert the tube on a paper towel for 1–2 min to completely remove all supernatant.
Add 150 μL DMEM (without additives) to the pellet.
Pause point: Samples can be stored at 4°C for 16–24 h. Do not exceed 24 h incubation.
Combine rehydrated virions from identical samples (if applicable).
Remove 100 μL for p24 measurement and HIV-1 infection assay (Janas and Wu, 2009[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).
Digest the virus with TURBO™ DNase for 30 min at 37°C.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1893_11.csv
Add 80 U (2 μL) RNaseOut™.
Store at −80°C or use directly for RNA extraction.
Pause point: Samples can be stored at −80°C until proceeding to the next step.
Alternatives: To confirm successful transfection and virus production, we routinely collect protein from one dish of HEK293T producer cells per condition for Western blot analysis of erasers and HIV-1 p24 expression (step 8). If the purified virus will be used for preparation of viral RNA only, DNase treatment can be performed after TRIzol™ purification rather than after resuspension of the virus pellet. In this case, TRIzol™ can be added directly to the ultracentrifuge tubes and all identical samples combined in 1 mL of TRIzol™. If generated HIV-1 stocks will be used for infections, perform DNase treatment as described in step 10 and freeze on dry ice and store in 20 μL aliquots at −80°C for future use. The virus titer decreases when using the stock after multiple freeze and thaw cycles. Thus, it is best to avoid multiple freeze and thaw cycles of virus stocks.
HIV-1 RNA extraction
Timing: 2 h
The purpose of this step is to extract HIV-1 genomic RNA from purified virions.

Biosafety Precautions for work with HIV-1NL4-3 may be discontinued after addition of TRIzol™ to concentrated virus.
Purify viral RNA using TRIzol™.
Add 1 mL of TRIzol™ Reagent to the centrifuge tube containing DNase-treated virions, pipet up and down several times to mix.
Incubate for 5 min at 22°C.
Add 0.2 mL of chloroform and mix well by vigorous shaking for 15 s. Do not vortex.
Incubate at 22°C for 15 min.
Centrifuge at 13,200 × g for 15 min at 4°C.
Transfer the colorless upper aqueous phase to a new tube.
Add 1 μL 20 mg/mL glycogen, mix.
Add 400 μL isopropanol, mix.
Incubate for 10 min at 22°C.
Centrifuge at 13,200 × g for 20 min at 4°C.
Carefully discard the supernatant without disturbing the pellet.
Wash the pellet in 1 mL 75% ethanol.
Centrifuge at 13,200 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant by decanting.
Pulse spin the tube to collect residual ethanol and remove using pipette.
Air dry the RNA pellet for 5 min.
Rehydrate the RNA in 50 μL RNase-free H2O.
Determine the concentration of RNA by Nanodrop and store RNA in −80°C.
Pause point: Samples can be stored at −80°C until proceeding to the next step.
HIV-1 RNA analysis by denaturing urea gel electrophoresis
Timing: 2 days
The purpose of this assay is to directly visualize and examine the integrity of the full-length extracted HIV-1 RNA.
Prepare electrophoresis reagents the day before electrophoresis.
Prepare 700 mL 1 M urea electrophoresis buffer. See recipe in “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]” section.
Dissolve at ≤60°C for 3 h with mixing at 400 rpm.
Prepare 8 M urea loading buffer. See recipe in “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]” section.
Vortex until dissolved.
Store at 4°C for 16–24 h or use immediately if performing same day electrophoresis.

Prepare 1 M urea/0.8% agarose gel the day of electrophoresis.
Add 0.8 g agarose to 94 mL 1× TAE. See recipe in “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]” section.
Dissolve in microwave and allow to cool to 60°C.
Add 6 g urea and mix 15 min to dissolve. The final volume will be 100 mL.
Pour into gel casting apparatus and allow to solidify.
Prepare samples for electrophoresis.
Bring 500 ng RNA sample to 5 μL using RNase-free H2O. Sample volume can be scaled up if necessary, based on RNA concentration (See Alternatives below).
Prepare Millenium™ ssRNA ladder by mixing 2 μL ladder with 3 μL RNase-free H2O.
To each sample and ladder add 20 μL 8 M urea loading buffer and 5 μL 6× Orange-G loading dye.
Denature samples for 5 min at 90°C and place immediately on ice.
Run denaturing urea agarose gel.
Place gel in buffer tank and immerse in electrophoresis buffer.
Load samples and run the gel until the loading dye (Orange-G) reaches 3/4 of the gel. (approximately 1.6 h at 85 V).
Remove gel and wash twice for 5 min each in 1× TAE buffer.
Immerse gel in ∼175 mL (1/4 volume of electrophoresis buffer used at step 12a) of 100 mM NaCl for 30 min.
Stain gel in SYBR Gold diluted 1:10,000 in 1× TAE for 30 min with gentle rocking and protected from light.
Image the gel using 300 nm UV transilluminator.
Alternatives: If visualization of RNA is the end-point assay, 500 ng RNA per well is sufficient. If the gel will also be used for Northern blot, 3 μg RNA should be loaded per well.

Critical: It is critical to maintain an RNase-free experimental environment to maintain RNA integrity throughout the procedure. All solutions should be prepared with RNase-free water. The gel tray, electrophoresis tank, pipettes, etc. may be treated with a commercially available RNase decontamination solution such as RNase ZAP™ prior to use. Viral RNA that is found to be degraded should not be used for downstream assays.
HIV-1 RNA analysis by northern blot (optional)
Timing: 2 days
The purpose of this assay is to specifically detect HIV-1 genomic RNA and its length using Northern blot. This is an optional step depending on the use of HIV-1 RNA.
Perform denaturing urea gel electrophoresis according to the previous section using 3 μg RNA per well.
Perform Northern blot using the NorthernMax™ Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific) according to the manufacturer’s protocol which can be found here: NorthernMax Kit[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2FMAN0019828_NorthernMax_UG.pdf].
Perform Nonisotopic probe detection using the Chemiluminescent Nucleic Acid Detection Module (Thermo Fisher Scientific) according to the manufacturer’s protocol which can be found here: Chemiluminescent Nucleic Acid Detection Module.
Alternatives: Once the protocol is well-established it is not strictly necessary to perform Northern blotting for every experiment.
HIV-1 RNA m6A detection by dot blot
Timing: 1–2 days
The purpose of this assay is to specifically detect m6A modifications of HIV-1 genomic RNA using a semi-quantitative dot blot assay.
Immobilize RNA to a nylon membrane.
Bring 220 ng RNA to 55 μL volume using of 1 mM EDTA pH 8.0.
Add 33 μL of 20× SSC buffer and 22 μL of 37% formaldehyde.
Mix and heat the samples at 65°C for 30 min. Transfer samples immediately to ice.
Use dot blot apparatus as a guide to cut a nylon membrane to the appropriate size for the required number of wells.

Soak the nylon membrane in 10× SSC buffer for 10 min.
Assemble the membrane in the dot blot apparatus following the manufacturer’s instructions.
Add 200 μL of RNase-free water to each well to be used and pull through using vacuum.
Add 200 μL of 10× SSC buffer to each well to be used and pull through using vacuum.
Load 100 μL of each sample and pull through using vacuum.
Wash each well twice with 200 μL 10× SSC buffer.
Keep the vacuum on and disassemble the instrument.
Place the membrane face up on a paper towel dampened with 10× SSC.
Place in the Stratalinker and perform autocrosslink (120,000 μJ/cm2) three times.
Critical: Do not handle the membrane with gloved hands. Only use clean forceps to handle the membrane. Always carefully read and follow instructions for dot blot apparatus.
Stain membrane with methylene blue to visualize RNA samples, which serves as a loading control for quantification of m6A levels.
Transfer the membrane to a small plastic dish.
Rinse the membrane in methylene blue stain for 1 min.
Rinse the membrane several times in ddH2O for ∼10 s each until background is de-stained and signal is appropriate for imaging.
Image the membrane.
Perform Western blot for m6A detection.
Block the membrane in 5% non-fat dry milk (NFDM) TBST for 60 min at 22°C.
Remove blocking solution and replace with 2.5% NFDM containing m6A primary antibody at a final concentration of 0.1 μg/mL (1:10,000 dilution).
Incubate for 60 min at 22°C or for 16–24 h at 4°C.
Pause point: Blot may be incubated with primary antibody for 16–24 h for convenience.
Wash the membrane in TBST three times for 5 min at 22°C.
Incubate with goat anti-rabbit HRP-conjugated secondary antibody in 2.5% NFDM TBST at a final concentration of 0.2 μg/mL (1:5000 dilution).

Wash the membrane in TBST five times for 5 min at 22°C.
Develop the membrane using SuperSignal™ West Femto Maximum Sensitivity Substrate according to manufacturer’s protocol which can be found here: SuperSignal West Femto Maximum Sensitivity Substrate[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2FMAN0011345_SupSig_West_Femto_MaxSensi_Subs_UG.pdf].
Image the membrane.
Use ImageJ to quantify the relative levels of m6A signal for each sample, using methylene blue signal as a loading control for normalization.
Alternatives: Antibody concentrations are for the specific antibodies listed in the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]. Any anti-rabbit HRP-conjugated secondary may be used; however, the optimal concentration would need to be determined empirically. Similarly, any chemiluminescent substrate system will work for development of signal from HRP-conjugated secondary antibodies. However, some substrates may not provide sufficient sensitivity to accurately quantify the m6A signal.
